awd_titl_txt: ERI: Integrable Nano-Optical Particle Sizer for Measuring Ultrafine Airborne Particles
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Ultrafine particles refer to airborne particles with diameters smaller than 100 nanometers. They are present in the ambient air we breathe and can be generated from many different sources such as combustion of fossil fuels, wildfire smoke, and cigarette smoke. Ultrafine particles can potentially pose severe health risks to a human body. Inhalation of ultrafine particles can cause pulmonary inflammation, systemic inflammation, and cardiovascular diseases. In order to investigate and monitor the health risks caused by ultrafine particles, wearable sensors that can measure the sizes of ultrafine particles at points of interest are highly demanded. Such sensors should be economic, compact, low-power, and integrable into digital mobile devices and aerosol delivery devices. Out of various techniques for measuring airborne particles, optical particle sizers hold great promise for realizing such sensor platforms. An optical particle sizer measures the sizes of individual airborne particles by detecting the light scattered from particles when they travel across a focused laser beam. However, in existing optical particle sizers based on conventional optics and low-cost optoelectronic components, the smallest detectable particle size is about 300 nanometers while ultrafine particles, being smaller than 100 nanometers, cannot be measured because of too weak light scattering from them. Responding to these challenges and limitations, this research project proposes a novel scheme of optical particle sizer based on a nano-optical sensor structure which can drastically boost the optical signals induced by ultrafine particles. The proposed research is aimed at developing an optical sensor platform capable of measuring ultrafine particles present in the ambient air and cigarette smoke, which can have great impacts on the improvement of the public health. The proposed research activities will provide training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in the field of optics, nanotechnology, and aerosol sensors, and will also encourage STEM participations for K-12 students through an outreach activity.

This research project will investigate the optical response of nano-optical structures when airborne ultrafine particles are located on the nanoscale hot spots of strongly focused light. Specifically, it will generate fundamental understanding on how to use subwavelength apertures in metal films to accurately measure the sizes of ultrafine particles flowing through the apertures. The project consists of three research objectives: 1) Model, fabricate, and characterize the subwavelength apertures. 2) Validate and calibrate the sensor's response to ultrafine particles. 3) Investigate the transport of ultrafine particles through subwavelength apertures. The project will evaluate the performance of the proposed sensor scheme including the smallest detectable particle size and detectable concentration, and study the effects of crucial factors such as the size of subwavelength apertures. The proposed research will lead to a breakthrough in optical particle sizers by extending the sensing capability into the desired ultrafine particle range. The proposed research will also advance the field of plasmonic sensors by enabling new applications in sensing airborne particles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ultrafine particles, also known as PM0.1, refer to airborne particles with diameters smaller than 100 nanometers (nm). They are present in the ambient air we breathe and can be generated from many various sources such as combustion of fossil fuels, wildfire smoke, and cigarette smoke. They can also contain biological materials such as airborne virus. Ultrafine particles can potentially pose severe health risks to a human body as they can easily be transported to the deep lung. Inhalation of ultrafine particles can cause pulmonary inflammation, systemic inflammation, and cardiovascular diseases.

In order to investigate and monitor the health risks caused by ultrafine particles, portable aerosol sensors that can measure the sizes of ultrafine particles at points of interest are highly demanded. Such sensors should be economic, compact, low-power, and integrable into portable devices. Out of various techniques for measuring airborne particles, optical approaches hold great promise for realizing such sensor platforms. Traditional optical approaches measure individual airborne particles by detecting the light scattered from the particles when they travel across a focused laser beam, however, the smallest detectable particle size is limited to about 300 nm. Therefore, ultrafine particles, being smaller than 100 nm, cannot be measured by traditional optical approaches because of too weak light scattering. Responding to these challenges and limitations, this research project investigated a novel scheme for aerosol sensing, referred to as a nano-optical particle sizer (NOPS), which can drastically boost the optical signals induced by ultrafine particles using a nanoscale aperture in a metal film, referred to as a metal nano-orifice. As shown in the figure, a metal nano-orifice of 300 nanometers diameter was fabricated into a suspended silicon nitrite (SiN) membrane. Aerosols of ultrafine particles were launched from one side the membrane and transported through the nano-orifice. A laser beam was focused onto the metal nano-orifice and the transmitted light was detected by a photodetector to acquire the optical signal. The intensity of light inside the nano-orifice was enhanced by many times due to plasmonic effects in metal nanostructures. When an ultrafine particle travels through the nano-orifice, an optical pulse is triggered in the signal. The figure shows an experimental result of an optical pulse triggered by a sodium chloride (NaCl) ultrafine particle of 80 nm diameter. 

During the two years funded by National Science Foundation, the principal investigator's (PI's) team has made groundbreaking discoveries in the proposed research. The team has successfully detected ultrafine particles as small as 58 nanometer in experiments, which is the first demonstration of detecting ultrafine particles using a direct optical approach. For the first time, the detection limit of optical particle sizer has been extended into the ultrafine range. The team has also demonstrated the first optofluidic setup for interfacing plasmonic sensors with aerosols, which opened new avenues for implementing plasmonic nanostructures in aerosol sensing, enabling significant applications in detecting bioaerosols and environmental aerosols. The team has also identified a challenge in the sensor scheme: the aerosol flow rate through the nano-orifice is too low, which limited the sensor's capability of counting ultrafine particles. The team's future research works will address such challenges.

The demonstrated sensor platform established a foundation for detecting ultrafine particles in ambient air and cigarette smoke, which can significantly improve public health. The PI's team also studied real-world aerosol sensing applications such as electronic cigarette aerosols and introduced compact aerosol sensors that can accurately monitor and track a user's puff topography. Funded by this NSF award, the PI's lab has provided excellent training opportunities for multiple graduate and undergraduate students in the field of optics, nanotechnology, biomedical engineering, and aerosol sensors. The PI's lab has also established comprehensive aerosol sensing facilities. Based on the aerosol instruments in the lab, an outreach module, "Facts about Vaping" summer camp workshop, has been successfully developed and delivered to local high school students. In this workshop, high school students conducted hands-on experiments on electronic cigarette aerosols to quantify particulate matter. This effectively raised their awareness about the health risks of vaping and encouraged their participation in STEM education. It should be noted that electronic cigarette usage disproportionately affects individuals from underrepresented groups and low socioeconomic backgrounds. Addressing this issue is essential to the team's commitment to promoting Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion.
